description: HENRICO COUNTY, Va.- Henrico's top prosecutor said Monday that her office could file hate crime charges against Harry Rogers, a Hanover man accused of revving his car's engine before driving into a crowd of protesters on Lakeside Avenue the day before. Commonwealth's Attorney Shannon Taylor cited Rogers' affiliation with the Ku Klux Klan, confirming that he...
text:
HENRICO COUNTY, Va. (WRIC) - Henrico's top prosecutor said Monday that her
office could file hate crime charges against Harry Rogers, a Hanover man
accused of revving his car's engine before driving into a crowd of protesters
on Lakeside Avenue the day before.

Commonwealth's Attorney Shannon Taylor cited Rogers' affiliation with the Ku
Klux Klan, confirming that he admitted to authorities that he considers
himself a leader of the group.

"The accused, by his own admission and by a cursory glance at social media, is
an admitted

leader of the Ku Klux Klan and a propagandist for Confederate ideology,"
Taylor wrote in a statement. "We are investigating whether hate crimes charges
are appropriate."

Rogers has already been charged with assault and battery, attempted malicious
wounding and felony vandalism, prosecutors said Monday.

"While I am grateful that the victim's injuries do not appear to be serious,
an attack on peaceful

protesters is heinous and despicable and we will prosecute to the fullest
extent of the law," Taylor's statement continued. "Yesterday, I participated
in a different peaceful protest for equality and justice in Henrico.
Protesters acting peaceably, well within their constitutional rights of
assembly, should not have to fear violence. We lived through this in Virginia
in Charlottesville in 2017. I promise Henricoans that this egregious criminal
act will not go unpunished. Hate has no place here under my watch."

This story is developing. Check back for updates.

LATEST HEADLINES:

* ETSU pitcher and Johnson City native hopes to hear his name in MLB draft

* Rev. Tallmadge Brown waits to visit wife as Gov. Lee gives guidance for long term care facilities

title: Virginia man accused of driving into protesters claims to be KKK leader, could face hate crime charges
html:
HENRICO COUNTY, Va. (WRIC) - Henrico's top prosecutor said Monday that her office could file hate crime charges against Harry Rogers, a Hanover man accused of revving his car's engine before driving into a crowd of protesters on Lakeside Avenue the day before.

Commonwealth's Attorney Shannon Taylor cited Rogers' affiliation with the Ku Klux Klan, confirming that he admitted to authorities that he considers himself a leader of the group.

"The accused, by his own admission and by a cursory glance at social media, is an admitted

leader of the Ku Klux Klan and a propagandist for Confederate ideology," Taylor wrote in a statement. "We are investigating whether hate crimes charges are appropriate."

Rogers has already been charged with assault and battery, attempted malicious wounding and felony vandalism, prosecutors said Monday.

"While I am grateful that the victim's injuries do not appear to be serious, an attack on peaceful

protesters is heinous and despicable and we will prosecute to the fullest extent of the law," Taylor's statement continued. "Yesterday, I participated in a different peaceful protest for equality and justice in Henrico. Protesters acting peaceably, well within their constitutional rights of assembly, should not have to fear violence. We lived through this in Virginia in Charlottesville in 2017. I promise Henricoans that this egregious criminal act will not go unpunished. Hate has no place here under my watch."

This story is developing. Check back for updates.
